title-group.article-title: Octonion structural response vector and potential structural damage identification method

article-meta.aff: School of Civil Engineering and Transportation, State Key Laboratory of Subtropical Building Science, South China University of Technology, Guangzhou, 510640, China

author-notes.corresp: Liqun Tang, School of Civil Engineering and Transportation, State Key Laboratory of Subtropical Building Science, South China University of Technology, Guangzhou 510640, China. Email: lqtang@scut.edu.cn

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: A promising method based on octonion structural response vector is proposed for the identification of structural damages according to the database acquired via long-term structural health monitoring. An octonion structural response vector consists of eight elements: seven for structural responses, including normalized static strains at specific positions and natural frequencies of a structure, and one for null. For a perfect structure the octonion structural response vector is a point in the phase plane, whereas for developing damages in the structure the octonion structural response vector manifests itself as a definite trajectory in the phase plane. Therefore, the development of damages in a structure could be investigated by analyzing the trajectory of octonion structural response vector obtained from the data of a long-term structural health monitoring or scheduled routine structural examinations. To demonstrate the implementation of this octonion structural response vector-based method, a two-dimensional numerical model of a simply-supported beam was built with crack-like damages of given location and depth. The octonion structural response vector of the beam corresponding to each state of damages was calculated to draw the trajectory related to the developing damages in the phase plane. The results show that the trajectories are significantly different for different devolvement of damages, even when the damages are in good symmetry. It indicates that the octonion structural response vector-based method recommended in the article could be effective to identify damages of structures using data of structures from long-term structural health monitoring or routine scheduled examinations.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: After structures are built and put into service, addition to the degeneracy of its material performance, structural damages will be inevitably affected by many factors such as loads (including overloads), rains, wind, seismic shock, fatigue, high and low temperatures, etc. Damage can be defined as changes of some specific properties of a structure, which will adversely affect the current or future performance of that structure (Doebling et al., 1996, 1998; Hu et al., 2001; Rytter, 1993; Salawu, 1997; Sohn et al., 2003). With the large number of structures being used despite aging and damage accumulating, structural health monitoring (SHM) becomes more and more important in many areas such as civil, mechanical and aerospace engineering (Doebling et al., 1996; Farrar et al., 2001; Sohn et al., 2003). As one of the most important parts of SHM, structural damage detection is developed in the recent decades accordingly (Doebling et al., 1996, 1998; Hu et al., 2001; Sohn et al., 2003). Structural damage detection is essentially an inverse problem (Engl et al., 1990; Trujillo, 1987), in which the damages are determined by analyzing structural response under certain conditions.

Rytter (1993) has pointed out that damage identification includes the following 4 level problems to be solved mainly.Level 1:
Determination that damage is present in the structure;Level 2:
Level 1 plus determination of the geometric location of the damage;Level 3:
Level 2 plus quantification of the severity of the damage;Level 4:
Level 3 plus prediction of the remaining service life of the structure.

In the recent decades, researches on structural damage detection based on vibration testing were prevalent world wide, most of these methods only cover the problems of the first three Levels (Doebling et al., 1996, 1998; Hu et al., 2001; Rytter, 1993; Sohn et al., 2003). Doebling et al. (1996, 1998) provided a detail overview and a summary review about these works up to 1996; Sohn et al. (2003) gave an updated review between 1996 and 2001. Carden and Fanning presented a review focused on the papers and articles published from 1996 to 2003. Yan et al. (2007) gave a summary review and discussed the development trend. The merits and drawbacks of vibration-based damage identification methods for beam- or plate-type structures were reviewed recently (Fan et al., 2011).
According to the type of structural response used, vibration-based structural damage detection methods can be mainly classified as frequency-based methods and mode-based methods.

Since the frequency-based methods are simple and easy to implement, great attention had been paid on them in damage detection research field (Doebling et al., 1996, 1998; Salawu, 1997). The early studies showed that the methods based on the changes of frequency can identify the existence of damage in structures (Fabrizio et al., 2000; Wang et al., 2001; Xia et al., 2003). Cawley and Adams (1979) proved that the ratio of frequency changes in two modes is a function of the location of the damage and succeeded in locating the damage in a structure. More detail works about frequency-based methods can be found in the reviews of Doebling et al. (1996), Fan and Qiao (2011) and Salawu (1997). However, there are still some drawbacks of the methods based on frequency. Firstly, the lower frequencies usually are not sensitive to damages while the higher frequencies (which are more sensitive to some damages) are difficult to be obtained in real structure. Secondly, the same frequency changes may be caused by different damages, such as the symmetric damages in symmetric structure. Furthermore, the effect of ambient conditions (temperature, moisture and wind, etc.) will cause the changes of frequency also, which will result in measurement errors of the dynamic test. Due to its inherent drawbacks, its applications for complex structures or multiple/severe damage detection are limited (Fan and Qiao, 2011).

Although the accuracy of vibration mode measurement is less than that of frequency, they are more sensitive to some small local changes in structure (Doebling et al., 1996). Therefore, the methods based on dynamic mode have also attracted much attention in the field of damage detection (Bagchi et al., 2010; Gulal et al., 2011; Hearn et al, 1991; Rezos et al, 1990; Shi et al., 2000; Song et al. 1986; West, 1984). Here the vibration mode has a generalized meaning, including mode shape (displacement), modal assurance criteria (MAC), the coordinate MAC (COMAC) and mode shape derivatives such as curvature and strain, etc. West may be the first one who used mode information (MAC) to locate damage in structures (West, 1984). Basing on mode shapes, Rizos, et al. (1990) had determined the length and location of crack in a beam. Since curvature or strain of the mode shape would be more sensitive than displacement mode shapes to some local damages, some scholars applied modes of curvature or strain as alternatives of mode shapes to detect structural damages (Abdel et al., 1999; Chen et al., 1994; Pandey et al., 1991; Qiao et al., 2007; Tsang, 1990; Xu et al., 1995). Pandey et al. (1991) demonstrated that the absolute change of mode shape curvature is a good indicator of damage in beam structure. Chen et al. (1994) identified the location of a crack in a cantilever plate based on strain mode shapes. But there are also some difficulties in applying mode-based methods to detect structural damage. Firstly, it is difficult to measure mode shapes of practical engineering structures because of many factors such as the system and observation noise of the modal measurement, the unknown full constraints of on-site conditions, etc. Secondly, since strain modes or curvature modes are the derivatives of mode shapes, any error in the measured mode shapes will directly affect the accuracy of strain modes or curvature modes, which will affect the result of damage recognition in turn.
Depending upon the type of analysis method, vibration-based structural damage detection methods mainly can be classified as matrix update methods and artificial neural networks (ANN) methods.

Any structure can be regarded as a mechanical system, which could be described with the stiffness, mass, damping matrix. Once a structure has damages, its property matrices (stiffness, mass and damping) will be modified accordingly. Matrix update method is based on the modification of intact structure property matrices to match the measured response of damaged structure as closely as possible (Bagchi et al., 2010; Baruch, 1978; Berman et al., 1983; Chen et al., 1980; Dyke et al., 2007; Friswell et al., 1999; Haug et al., 1984; Hemez, 1993; Kabe, 1985; Kaouk et al., 1993, 1994; Lam et al., 1998; Messina et al., 1998; Norris et al., 1989; Parloo et al., 2003; Zhang, 1999; Zimmerman et al., 1994). The damage is detected through comparing the updated matrices and the original matrices. There are two main categories of matrix update methods which are used the most widely: optimal matrix update methods and sensitivity-based update methods. Optimal matrix update methods directly compute the damaged property matrices through solving a Lagrange multiplier or penalty-based optimization (Baruch, 1978; Berman et al., 1983; Kabe, 1985). Early studies of these methods were based on minimization of the norm of stiffness or mass matrix, the constrains usually were matrix symmetry, orthogonality and zero modal force error, etc. (Baruch, 1978; Berman et al., 1983; Dyke et al., 2007; Friswell et al., 1999; Kabe, 1985; Zhang, 1999). Later researches were focus on the minimum rank perturbation theory (MRPT) (Kiran, 2008; Zimmerman and Kaouk 1993, 1994). In sensitivity-based update methods, the property parameters (or matrix) to be modified are determined according to the result of sensitivity analysis first. Since the property parameters selected to be modified are usually sensitive to structural responds, the modification is more targeted and efficient. Chen and Garba (1980) proposed an experimental sensitivity-based matrix update approach, they used the orthogonality of mode shape to compute modal parameter (frequency and modal vector) sensitivity. An analytical sensitivity-based matrix update procedure was presented by Hemez (1993) to estimate the sensitivity of stiffness and mass matrix. Anyway, there are some confounding factors restricting the application of matrix update methods. Firstly, these methods always require a large number of iterative calculations since the amount of optimal variables usually are huge. Secondly, in order to make sure the number of measured freedoms equal to analysis model, a modal reduction or modal expansion (Friswell et al., 1999) is always needed. That will cause extra errors, and affect the damage detection result. Furthermore, the modifications cannot generally maintain the positive definite of stiffness matrix and the connectivity of the elements, so the accuracy of damage identification cannot be guaranteed.

ANN has recently been used to detect damage based on training a set of samples which reflect the mapping of different damages to the measured structural responses (Barai et al., 1995; Chen et al., 1995; Elkordy et al., 1993; Kanwar et al., 2007; Kirkegaard et al., 1994; Leath et al., 1993; Sahin et al., 2003; Soheil, 2003; Szewczyk et al., 1994; Venkatasubramanian et al., 1989; Wu et al., 1992). ANN can diagnose structural damages without parameter identification and a prior knowledge of dynamic characteristics, which may greatly simplify the solving process of damage detection. ANN was first applied to detect damage and estimate health in engineering structures by Venkatasubramanian and Chan (1989). Later research schemes mainly focus on network construction and the selection of network input variables. Although ANN can map new patterns of response to new damage type and location, there are still some difficulties need to be solved. Firstly, ANN cannot consider the expert empiric knowledge, so the training may have great randomness and blindness. Secondly, because the results are accurate only if the pattern matches one of the examples of the training set, this kind of methods need a large number of samples to be trained in the network. But the training samples are limited in practice, so it is difficult to obtain a convergent global optimal solution.

No algorithm has yet been proposed, which can be applied universally to identify any type of damage in any type of structure (Carden and Fanning, 2004). In this article, a promising method based on octonion structural response vector (OSRV) was proposed for the purpose of damage detection. Firstly, the basic concepts of octonion and the definition of OSRV are presented. Secondly, to illustrate the implementation of this method, a 2D numerical model of a simply-supported beam was built with crack-like damages of given location and depth. The OSRV of the beam corresponding to each state of damages was calculated, and the trajectory of the OSRV in each evolvement mode of damages was drawn in the phase plane. Thirdly, the problem of symmetrical damage was discussed, through the feature (mode and angle) of OSRV and composite product of vector algorithms, the method succeeds in proving that the symmetric damages will cause symmetric character for OSRV. Finally, some conclusions are summarized.

sec.title: Basic concepts of octonion
sec.p: The octonions were discovered in 1843 by John T Graves (John, 2002). An octonion x→ is a real linear combination of the unit octonions (1)x→=x0e→0+x1e→1+x2e→2+x3e→3+x4e→4+x5e→5+x6e→6+x7e→7

In which {xi} are real numbers; {e→0, e→1, e→2, e→3, e→4, e→5, e→6, e→7} are the unit octonions, and e→0 is the scalar element 1. The key of the unit octonions is the definition of the multiplication of the unit octonions, which is reflected in Table 1.

Now, let us consider a special group of octonions with the real number x0≡0, for these octonions, the dot product and cross product of any two octonions a→,b→ are defined as (2)a→·b→=-12(a→b→+b→a→)a→×b→=12(a→b→-b→a→) Where, a→b→=aibje→ie→j,b→a→=aibje→je→i and e→ie→j will become another base vector, which obeys the rule defined in Table 1. With the definition in equation (2), a→·b→=aibi is a scalar, c→=a→×b→is an octonion with c0=0. Table 1.
Cayley’s octonion multiplication table.
e→0 e→1 e→2 e→3 e→4 e→5 e→6 e→7
e→1 −1 e→3 −e→2 e→5 −e→4 −e→7 e→6
e→2 −e→3 −1 e→1 e→6 e→7 −e→4 −e→5
e→3 e→2 −e→1 −1 e→7 −e→6 e→5 −e→4
e→4 −e→5 −e→6− −e→7 −1 e→1 e→2 e→3
e→5 e→4 −e→7 e→6 −e→1 −1 −e→3 e→2
e→6 e→7 e→4 −e→5 −e→2 e→3 −1 −e→1
e→7 −e→6 e→5 e→4 −e→3 −e→2 e→1 −1

sec.title: Structural response vector
sec.p: In fact, the structure responses include both dynamic and static responses, such as, natural frequencies and modes of the vibration of the structure, deformation energy, strains or displacements at some specific positions in the structure, so on. Since the most common responses obtained in a routine loading test of bridges are strains at specific locations and natural frequencies, which are easily measured by mature instruments with high accuracy. We integrate the strains (as static responses) and natural frequencies (as dynamic responses) of a structure to construct a structural response vector (SRV), which related the current states of a structure directly (Tang et al., 2010).

sec.title: 1. Strain elements
sec.p: If a structure has served for a period of time, the damages of the structure reach to an extent, we named the structure at state i. The measured strains in the state i are ɛpi (p=1,2,…,n) at different location p. When i=0, it means that the structure is in a state without damage. Normalizing the strains by the forms (3)ξ1i=ɛ1iɛ10,ξ2i=ɛ2iɛ20,…,ξni=ɛniɛn0

Specially, the normalized strain elements ξpi (p=1,2,…,n) will be 1 when the structures have no damages. We call ξpi strain elements. The strain elements are selectable in different structures for the better response sensitivity.

sec.title: 2. Frequency elements
sec.p: Analogously, the natural frequencies (which can be obtained by routine dynamic test on a structure) of the structure without damage are f10,f20,…,fm0. For the state i, the natural frequencies of structures become f1i,f2i,…,fmi, and the normalized frequencies elements ψqi (q=1,2,…,m) take the forms (4)ψ1i=f1if10,ψ2i=f2if20,…,ψmi=fmifm0
Particularly, if the structures have no damages, ψqi (q=1,2,…,m) would be equal to 1, we name ψqi frequency elements.
Now, let us take ξpi and ψqi as elements of a multi-dimensional vector in the following (5)Vi={ξ1iξ2i…ξniψ1iψ2i…ψmi}T={v1iv2i…vn+mi}T
We call Vi the structure response vector. Of course the SRV is a generalized concept, the definition of its elements would be more than the above definition.

sec.title: Octonion structural response vector
sec.p: For a vector, there are two key features: mode and orientation in the vector space, which are also keys in upcoming structural damage identification. The mode of a vector depends on its dot product; the orientation mainly relative orientation to another vector depends on their dot and cross products. If there are more elements of the SRV, the state of a structure may be determined more accurate. Unfortunately, only the vectors of quaternion or octonion with x0≡0 support the dot and cross product. Vectors of quaternion with x0≡0 degenerates to vectors in Euclidean space, but there are only three independent elements, which are too few to determine the state of a structure uniquely. Vectors of octonion with x0≡0 have seven elements, which is better to determine the state of a structure.

How to choose the seven elements in an OSRV is an important question waiting for intensive study for different kinds of structures and loads. Here, we choose three strain elements and four frequency elements for a 2D beam. An OSRV may be expressed as (6)Vi={0ξ1iξ2iξ3iψ1iψ2iψ3iψ4i}T={0v1i…v7i}T

sec.title: Evolution of OSRV in a simply-supported beam with damages
sec.p: In order to show the potential application of the OSRV in structural damage identification, the responses of a simply-supported beam were used for an example.

sec.title: Basic information of the simply-supported beam
sec.p:
The beam had the following dimensions: 16 m span, 1.2 m height, 0.2 m thickness. Here, there was one vertical crack from the bottom up with height h (meter), the location of the crack was X meter (shown in Figure 1) to the left end of the beam. Three measurement points of strains (N1–N3) are selected in Figure 1 (at the top of the beam in the span of 1/4, 1/2 and 3/4), they are usually selected in routine engineering tests of a bridge. Figure 1.
Simply-supported beam with damage.
The strains were used as the static response elements in the OSRV. As for dynamic elements, first four natural frequencies are used.

sec.title: Finite element model
sec.p:
For such a beam with crack, a 2D FEM model was set up by ANSYS to get its related static and dynamic responses. The element type is plan42, the finite element mesh size is 0.04 m, and the element numbers are 13,200. The structural finite element meshes are shown in Figure 2, in which the crack is modeled with limit width. Figure 2.
The 2-dimension FEM of the simply-supported beam.
FEM: finite element method.

Some concentrated forces are applied on the beam (shown as Figure 3), which are simplified from an equivalent truck load used in a bridge routine static test. Figure 3.
The equivalent vehicle loads on the beam.

The analysis included the different crack heights h increased from 0 m to 0.4 m with an increment of 0.04 m, and crack position is at the mid-span (X = 8 m). Totally 11 states of different damages were studied, and each crack height meant the beam to be in a different state. The states with crack height = 0, 0.04, 0.08, … , 0.4 (m) were given numbers i = 0, 1, 2, … , 10, respectively.

sec.title: The analysis of numerical results
sec.p:
Based on the finite element model, the static and dynamic responses of the beam in different states can be calculated, and the details of three states (0 (h = 0 m), 5 (h = 0.16 m) and 9 (h = 0.32 m)) were shown in Table 2 as examples. Table 2.
The strains and frequencies of FEM.
Components State 0 (no damage) State 5 (h = 0.16 m) State 9 (h = 0.32 m)
Strain (point 1) −0.000205 −0.000204 −0.000200
Strain (point 2) −0.000335 −0.000360 −0.000416
Strain (point 3) −0.000205 −0.000204 −0.000200
1st frequency 11.410 11.349 11.198
2nd frequency 28.017 28.018 28.017
3rd frequency 58.521 58.526 58.526
4th frequency 68.536 67.539 64.934
FEM: finite element method.

According to equations (1) and (2), the normalized strains and frequencies are shown in Table 3. Table 3.
Normalized strains and frequencies.
Components State 0 State 5 State 9
Strain (point 1) 1 0.993 0.974
Strain (point 2) 1 1.072 1.240
Strain (point 3) 1 0.993 0.974
1st frequency 1 0.995 0.981
2nd frequency 1 1.000 1.000
3rd frequency 1 1.000 1.000
4th frequency 1 0.985 0.947
From the data in Table 2, the OSRVs in the three cases of state are shown as follows (7)V0={01111111}V5={00.9931.0720.9930.9951.0001.0000.985}V9={00.9741.2400.9740.9811.0001.0000.947}

sec.title: Mode of OSRV
sec.p: According to the definition of vector space, the mode of an OSRV is (8)Mi=|Vi|=(Vi·Vi)1/2
Then, the modes of OSRVs in equation (5) are (9){M0=2.646M5=2.661M9=2.701

The general feature of the mode varied with damages as shown in Figure 4, which means that the mode of the OSRV increases with the increment of height of damage. Figure 4.
The mode of the OSRV vs. the height of crack.
OSRV: octonion structural response vector.

sec.title: Orientation of OSRV
sec.p: Another key property of a vector is its orientation in the vector space. Here, θi is the included angle of Vi and V0 as an index of the orientation of the OSRV. (10)cosθi=Vi·V0|Vi|·|V0|orθi=arccos(Vi·V0|Vi|·|V0|)
According to the definition of the angle θi, the angles of two damage state i = 0, 5, 9 are (11)θ0=0(rad)θ5=0.0275(rad)θ9=0.0909(rad)

The general feature of the angle varying with damages can also be shown in Figure 5, which means that the direction angle increases with the increment of height of damage. Figure 5.
The angle vs. the height of damage.

sec.title: The OSRV trajectory in phase plane of the mode and the direction angle
sec.p: In fact, the damages (with specific height) may be illustrated in a phase plane in which the two coordinates are the model Mi of OSRV and direction angle θi.

For a given damage state of the structure, there may be a unique point existing in the phase plane (waiting for strict proof), and for a specific developing damage there would be a trajectory to depict the responding states in the phase plane.

For the damages depicted in Figure 1, the trajectory of the OSRV reflected in the phase is shown in Figure 6. Figure 6.
The trajectory of the OSRV in the phase plane with the given mode of damages.
OSRV: octonion structural response vector.

sec.title: Idea of the damage identification by OSRV in the phase plane
sec.p: Theoretically, if we do enough numerical analysis, and record the OSRVs with all damages, we may identify the damage by detecting the OSRV of the structure currently. But it is unfeasible practically, since it is impossible to calculate the OSRVs of the structure with all the possible damages, and that may lead to great error in identifying the damage by comparing 7 elemental values of a measured OSRV with that of all theoretical OSRVs.

Here, according to an engineering experience, the modes of damages of a structure are usually limited to several kinds. For each mode of damages, the development of damages results in a series of OSRVs, which reflects a definite trajectory in the phase plane. Then, the different kinds of damages will induce limited several trajectories of the OSRV in the phase plane by pre-analysis. The routine inspection of the structure or long-term health monitoring may help to provide the serial OSRVs of the structure, which helps to draw a trajectory (called measured trajectory) about the structure in the phase plane. We may identify the mode and extension of damages of the structure by comparing the modes and the direction angles of measured OSRVs with pre-analysis trajectories.
If elements in OSRV are different, trajectories of OSRV with damages in the phase plane will be different. But for selected 7 elements OSRV, the trajectory is definite with given damages.

sec.title: The problem of symmetrical damages
sec.p: If the damage location X (shown in Figure 1) changes, the trajectory may change accordingly. Now, two special cases with symmetrical damages positions are considered, and two special locations X=4 m and X=12 m located at the span of 1/4 and 3/4 respectively were taken as examples.

In each case of damage location, there are 11 states of structure with different crack heights as that in the case of middle span damage location, the load and boundary conditions are the same as shown in Figure 2. The normalized elements of OSRVs at the states of damage height, h = 0.16 m and h = 0.32 m, are shown in Tables 4 and 5. Table 4.
Normalized strains and frequencies with X = 4 m.
Components State 0 State 5 State 9
No damage h = 0.16 m h = 0.32 m
Strain (point 1) 1 1.045 1.138
Strain (point 2) 1 0.998 0.993
Strain (point 3) 1 0.997 0.988
1st frequency 1 0.999 0.997
2nd frequency 1 0.989 0.961
3rd frequency 1 0.999 0.997
4th frequency 1 0.998 0.995
Table 5.
Normalized strains and frequencies with X = 12 m.
Components State 0 State 5 State 9
No damage h = 0.16 m h = 0.32 m
Strain (point 1) 1 0.997 0.988
Strain (point 2) 1 0.998 0.993
Strain (point 3) 1 1.045 1.138
1st frequency 1 0.999 0.997
2nd frequency 1 0.989 0.961
3rd frequency 1 0.999 0.997
4th frequency 1 0.998 0.995

From the two tables, it can be concluded that the OSRV can distinguish the two symmetrical damages clearly. But the modes and the direction angles introduced in equations (8) and (10) are same for the two symmetrical damages, which are illustrated as Mx=45=2.656,Mx=49=2.676,θx=45=0.0171(rad),θx=49=0.0530(rad);Mx=125=2.656,Mx=129=2.676,θx=125=0.0171(rad),θx=129=0.0530(rad).

Here, that the modes of the OSRVs with different kinds of damage are same is acceptable, but why is that the direction angles are same when the OSRVs appear different? The key lies in the definition of the direction angle in equation (10), in which the direction angle is calculated by the anti-operation of its cosine. The anti-operation cannot tell whether the angle is negative or positive.

But, if the direction angles are different for two vectors, there is a method to distinguish them as shown in Figure 7. First of all, we regard that there is a symmetrical plane for SVRs with position x = 4 m and x = 12 m, which is defined by two vectors V0 and P→ (Figure 7), where the vector P→ is defined as (12)P→=Vx=4i×Vx=12i (i=1,or,2,or,…,n) Figure 7.
Sketch of symmetrical OSRVs in the vector space.
OSRV: octonion structural response vector.
And, we take P→=Vx=45×Vx=125 as an example. Now, the normal direction of the symmetrical plane is the same as the following vector Q→ which is expressed as (13)Q→=P→×V0=(Vx=45×Vx=125)×V0
Therefore, any two plane-symmetric vectors can be distinguished by a scalar operation (14)Δi=Vi·Q→=Vi·(P→×V0)=Vi·[(Vx=45×Vx=125)×V0]
If Δi is negative the OSRV will locate at x = 4 m, or x = 12 m. Here, we define that the direction angle of a Vi with negative Δi is negative, and the Vi with a positive Δi is positive.
According to the vector operation rule (15)(a→×b→)×c→=b→(a→·c→)-a→(b→·c→)
Equation (14) can be changed to (16)Δi=Vi·[(Vx=45×Vx=125)×V0]=(Vi·Vx=125)(Vx=45·V0)-(Vi·Vx=45)(Vx=125·V0)

With equation (16), the Δi of the OSRVs in different damage states at location x = 4 m and 12 m are listed in Table 6. It is shown that there do exist opposite value of Δi corresponding to symmetrical damages. Table 6.
The result forVi·Q→.
Crack height Vx=4i·Q→ Vx=12i·Q→
0.04 −0.0004 0.0004
0.08 −0.0015 0.0015
0.12 −0.0030 0.0030
0.16 −0.0049 0.0049
0.2 −0.0071 0.0071
0.24 −0.0096 0.0096
0.28 −0.0123 0.0123
0.32 −0.0152 0.0152
0.36 −0.0181 0.0181
0.4 −0.0211 0.0211
With the definition of Δi, the direction angle referring to the plane defined by vectors V0 and P→ will be defined by the following (10) (17)θi=π2-arccos(Δi|Vi|·|Q→|)

Then, the states of the structure with symmetrical damages can be clearly distinguished in the phase plane (Figure 8). Figure 8.
The trajectory of symmetrical OSRVs in the phase plane with the given mode of damages.
OSRV: octonion structural response vector.

sec.title: Conclusions and remarks
sec.p:
Based on structural measurable responses (the static strain and vibration frequency), a kind of octonion structural response vector (OSRV) are recommended to identify the damages of structures in a mode-angle phase plane of OSRV. A simply-supported beam was taken as an example to show the application of the OSRVs to index different damages in the phase plane. Some conclusions and remarks may be drawn as:
The method of OSRV may provide a new way to structural damage identification by combining the static responses with the dynamic responses effectively, which can reflect the structural states more natively and reliably, and also provides a broad choice to define OSRV for different structures with corresponding damages.
The example shows that the method recommended in the article, including the component normalization, elemental definitions in OSRV and mode-angle phase plane, is feasible to identify even symmetric damages effectively. And OSRVs of different damages do map different point in the mode-angle plane.
With the features (mode and angle) of OSRV and the algorithm of vector composite product, the OSRV-based method may utilize the data from long-term structural health monitoring for structural damage identification.
There is still a long way to go for different structures with corresponding damages to develop effective OSRV-based method, such as, the selection of 7 response in OSRV, the trajectory properties of the OSRVs in the phase plane with damages.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: The authors wish to express their gratitude to the supports provided by Natural Science Foundation of China (10872070, 50908089) and State Key Laboratory of Subtropical Building Science (2012ZC24).
